docs.lead_paragraph: Ultrasound treatment can give short-term relief to people with painful tendinitis in the shoulder, a study has found. The study, published in the current issue of The New England Journal of Medicine, looked at the effectiveness of ultrasound in breaking down the calcium deposits in the rotator cuff that cause shoulder tendinitis.

headline.main: Good Vibrations to Ease Shoulder Pain

docs.abstract: Study finds that ultrasound treatment can give short-term relief to people with painful tendinitis in shoulder (M)
docs.snippet: Ultrasound treatment can give short-term relief to people with painful tendinitis in the shoulder, a study has found.    The study, published in the current issue of The New England Journal of Medicine, looked at the effectiveness of ultrasound in...

docs.lead_paragraph: It was the early 1970's, the heyday of mini-skirts and quick weight-loss schemes, when fashion magazines and celebrity dieters propelled Dr. Robert C. Atkins's ''diet revolution'' into a national phenomenon. His book, ''Dr. Atkins' Diet Revolution,'' promoted a high-fat, high-protein diet spurning most carbohydrates. Many nutritionists and public health experts were dismayed, but 10 million Americans were undeterred. Their reliance on labor-saving devices and fast foods had spawned thunder thighs and rendered their waistlines a thing of the past. They made the book a best seller.

headline.main: Doubts Fail to Deter 'The Diet Revolution'

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on renewed popularity of high-fat, high-protein, low-carbohydrate diet promoted by Dr Robert C Atkins in early 1970'; cites lack of studies of diet's long-term results or safety; notes depleting body of stored carbohydrates causes initial loss of water, weight quickly regained with first starchy food eaten; cites risks; photo (M)
docs.snippet: It was the early 1970's, the heyday of mini-skirts and quick weight-loss schemes, when fashion magazines and celebrity dieters propelled Dr. Robert C. Atkins's ''diet revolution'' into a national phenomenon. His book, ''Dr. Atkins' Diet Revolution,''...

docs.lead_paragraph: The weight-loss drug Xenical, approved last month, had barely reached the market when Web sites selling the drug sprang up to tap into the intense consumer demand that accompanies the debut of anything marketed to make people lose weight. But in their eagerness for pills to help them slim down, people may conveniently overlook something that doctors remember all too well: weight-loss drugs in general have have a rather alarming history.

headline.main: History Counsels Caution on Diet Pills

docs.abstract: History of weight-loss drugs that caused major medical problems recalled in light of instant demand for newly approved drug Xenical; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The weight-loss drug Xenical, approved last month, had barely reached the market when Web sites selling the drug sprang up to tap into the intense consumer demand that accompanies the debut of anything marketed to make people lose weight.     But in...

docs.lead_paragraph: Many teen-agers experience stress, but the patterns of stress girls encounter may leave them more vulnerable to depression than those boys experience, according to a study that appears in the current issue of the journal Child Development. The researchers interviewed 88 youths, ages 8 to 18, who were receiving treatment at several mental health clinics in an effort to link stressful experiences to depression. Their parents were also interviewed.

headline.main: What Stress Can Mean to Teen-Age Girls

docs.abstract: Study by Dr Karen D Rudolph finds patterns of stress teen-age girls encounter may leave them more vulnerable to depression than those boys experience; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Many teen-agers experience stress, but the patterns of stress girls encounter may leave them more vulnerable to depression than those boys experience, according to a study that appears in the current issue of the journal Child Development.    The...

docs.lead_paragraph: For various reasons, including a busy schedule and two herniated discs in my neck, I got out of shape. Or, more specifically, I got into another shape altogether. Then, last fall, while doing Internet research for an article about women's bodybuilding, I stumbled onto a site named trulyhuge.com. What this site was selling seemed highly unlikely: on-line training.

headline.main: Some Shape Up by Surfing the Internet

docs.abstract: Marion Roach article on using Web site that offers on-line fitness training; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: For various reasons, including a busy schedule and two herniated discs in my neck, I got out of shape. Or, more specifically, I got into another shape altogether.    Then, last fall, while doing Internet research for an article about women's...

docs.lead_paragraph: Though it has been well established that most peptic ulcers are caused by a bacteria called Helicobacter pylori, or H. pylori, and can be effectively treated with antibiotics, recent studies show that the information has not gotten out to ulcer sufferers and that a large number of doctors are continuing to treat with standard acid blockers only. ''There is a lack of awareness among physicians and consumers,'' Dr. Benjamin D. Gold, a professor at the Emory University School of Medicine in Atlanta, said at the annual meeting of the American Gastroenterological Association in Orlando, Fla.

headline.main: Outdated Views on Ulcers Hinder Cures

docs.abstract: Studies by Dr Benjamin D Gold and researchers at Centers for Disease Control and Prevention find that many adults are unaware that peptic ulcers are caused by bacteria and can be effectively treated with antibiotics and that even though most doctors know bacteria causes most ulcers, they continue to prescribe acid-blocking therapy for first-time patients (M)
docs.snippet: Though it has been well established that most peptic ulcers are caused by a bacteria called Helicobacter pylori, or H. pylori, and can be effectively treated with antibiotics, recent studies show that the information has not gotten out to ulcer...

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION

docs.lead_paragraph: Now hear this: avocados, walnuts, salad dressings with oil, sauteed vegetables, fatty fish and some kinds of margarine may be back on the menu for health-conscious Americans, even for those trying to lose weight, if the findings of recent studies are to be believed. For three decades now, Americans have been bombarded with advice to eat less fat for the sake of their hearts and their waistlines. One well-known expert, Dr. Dean Ornish, advocates stripping away all added fats and naturally fatty foods to achieve a diet containing no more than 10 percent of calories from fat, down from the 44 percent typically consumed by Americans in the 1960's and the 34 percent now consumed.

headline.main: New Look At Dieting: Fat Can Be A Friend

docs.abstract: Specialists on nutrition, health and obesity say stripping fat from American diet seems to have backfired, with obesity up 50 percent since big push to limit fat took off in 1970's; blame replacement of fat in diet with excessive amounts of carbohydrates; stress importance of limiting total calories in diet and deriving benefits of fats in such foods as avocados, walnuts, salad oil and fatty fish; graph of types of fats in various oils (M)
docs.snippet: Now hear this: avocados, walnuts, salad dressings with oil, sauteed vegetables, fatty fish and some kinds of margarine may be back on the menu for health-conscious Americans, even for those trying to lose weight, if the findings of recent studies are...

docs.lead_paragraph: Research into the safety of a margarine that may have a beneficial effect on cholesterol levels has passed a review by examiners for the Food and Drug Administration, the Federal agency said last week. The action clears the way for the margarine to be sold in the United States by McNeil Consumers Health Care.

headline.main: Seeking Better Health on a Slice of Bread

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration examiners reviews research into safety of the margarine Benecol and clears it for sale in US by McNeil Consumers Health Care, which say the plant stanol ester in the margarine will help consumers control blood cholesterol; FDA says it does not endorse product or its claims; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Research into the safety of a margarine that may have a beneficial effect on cholesterol levels has passed a review by examiners for the Food and Drug Administration, the Federal agency said last week.    The action clears the way for the margarine...

docs.lead_paragraph: It is a depressing article of faith among the overweight and those who treat them that 95 percent of people who lose weight regain it -- and sometimes more -- within a few months or years. That statistic has been quoted widely over the last four decades, in Congressional hearings, diet books, research papers and seminars. And it is the reason so many people approach dieting with a sense of hopelessness.

headline.main: 95% Regain Lost Weight. Or Do They?

docs.abstract: Obesity researchers reject as myth the often cited statistic that 95 percent of people who lose weight regain it; seek to determine how many people have succeeded and study success stories for lessons that might inspire others; Drs Rena Wing and James O Hill, studying long-term dieters for National Weight Control Registry project, say they have easily identified 2,500 people who have succeeded; successful dieters comment; photos (M)
docs.snippet: It is a depressing article of faith among the overweight and those who treat them that 95 percent of people who lose weight regain it -- and sometimes more -- within a few months or years.    That statistic has been quoted widely over the last four...

docs.lead_paragraph: I have seen the future -- and I prefer the past. Or is it the other way around? The glimpses of what was and what could be came courtesy of a recent visit to a ''body-morphing station.'' The computerized gizmo is not unlike a fun-house mirror that distorts your image until you appear ridiculously thin or grotesquely fat. But here the goal was not idle amusement but education (O.K., it was really a way to help shill a new product, but we'll get to that later).

headline.main: Body Computer Shows Shape of Things to Come

docs.abstract: Eric Nagourney article on testing 'body-morphing station' Hoffman-La Roche uses to help promote new weight-loss drug, Xenical; machine enables user to see what they would look like if they lost or gained weight and shows how chances of contracting various weight-related maladies shift with weight changes; photo (M)
